title: Dollar General: healthcare push a natural next step for retail star
text:
“Chief medical officer at Dollar General” sounds like an odd job title. The discount store chain specialises in selling cheap goods to low-income Americans often in rural, underserved areas. That has brought it success rare for a physical retailer. Now with more than 17,000 stores dotting America and a market worth of more than $50bn, it is exploring new avenues to keep up its breakneck growth.

On Wednesday, the business announced that it would expand its healthcare offerings to common over-the-counter treatments for everyday needs. It has hired Albert Wu, a physician-turned-McKinsey consultant, as CMO to oversee the healthcare push.

The company has announced no plans to get into the pharmacy business. But with healthcare spending in the US chewing up a fifth of the economy, healthcare is a part of its customer's wallet it can no longer ignore.

Dollar General says core customers earn less than $40,000 per year. Their finances are precarious enough that they often choose canned fruits over fresh to save money. Stores are smaller than a Walmart or traditional grocery and have a limited product assortment.

In a polarised US economy, this is a sweet spot. In the past five years, Dollar General shares are up 136 per cent while supermarket chain Kroger is flat. In 2020, same-store sales jumped 16 per cent, the 31st straight year of increases.

Dollar General's next act will however be trickier as it trades at a robust 20 times forward earnings. It is rolling out larger stores and trying to get customers to buy “non-consumables” as well as perishable, fresh foods. OTC health products are a natural next step given the consumer traffic stores generate.

Could Dollar General do something bolder?

Its customers are an underserved population. Healthcare is increasingly focused on wellness and preventive care. Dr Wu, an expert in rural healthcare, has a chance to make the chain a helpful outpost among marginalised people. The company has been maligned for “exploitation”, as often happens to businesses catering to the working poor. Low-cost, in-store pharmacies or clinics would give the lie to that accusation — and foster footfall.
